document_data.title: Dragon and Dungeon Transition

History.Wizards of the Coast: [[Wizards of the Coast]] purchased TSR and its intellectual properties, including ''Dragon'', in 1997. Production was then transferred from Wisconsin to Washington state. In 1999, Wizards of the Coast was itself purchased by [[wikipedia:Hasbro|Hasbro]], ''Dragon'' suffered a five-month gap between [[Dragon magazine 236|#236]] and [[Dragon magazine 237|#237]] but remained published by TSR as a subsidiary of WotC starting September 1997 with [[Dragon magazine 239|issue #239]],<ref>''[[Dragon magazine 239|issue #239]]''(1997-09) and until [[Dragon magazine 267|#267]] in January 2000 when Wizards of the Coast became the listed ''de facto'' publisher.<ref>''[[Dragon magazine 267|#267]]'' (2000-01)
History.Paizo Publishing:
In 2002, [[Paizo Publishing]] acquired the rights to publish both ''Dragon'' and '' Dungeon'' under license from Wizards of the Coast. '' Dragon'' was published by Paizo starting September 2002 with [[Dragon magazine 299|issue #299]]. It tied ''Dragon'' more closely to ''Dungeon'' by including articles supporting and promoting its major multi-issue adventures such as the "Age of Worms" and "Savage Tide". "Class Acts", monthly one- or two-page articles offering ideas for developing specific character classes, were also introduced by Paizo.

On April 18, 2007, Wizards of the Coast announced that it would not be renewing Paizo's licenses for ''Dragon''. The final printed issue was [[Dragon magazine 359|#359]] in September 2007.

History.Digital:
Shortly after the last print issue shipped, Wizards of the Coast re-launched ''Dragon'' as an online magazine, continuing the issue numbering of the print edition. The first digital edition was [[Dragon magazine 360|#360]] in October 2007

In [[Dragon magazine 427|Issue #427]] (September 2013), an article by Wizards of the Coast game designer and editor [[Chris Perkins]] announced that ''Dragon'' would be going on hiatus starting January 2014 pending the release of ''Dungeons & Dragons'' 5{{th}} edition. <ref>{{Cite dragon/427/Editorial: Going Dark}} The final edition of ''Dragon'' released was issue [[Dragon magazine 430|#430]] in December 2013.
History.Dragon+: A new and fully digital bi-monthly publication called ''[[Dragon+]]'', was launched on April 30, 2015,<ref>{{Cite dragon+/1/Letter From The Editor}} succeeding the existing versions of ''Dragon'' and ''Dungeon'' magazines. Created by Dialect in collaboration with Wizards of the Coast, the online edition ceased continuity with the printed and digital versions of both magazines and restarted its numbering system for issues at No. 1.

document_data.In the Realms: [[Ed Greenwood]] had his first published article in issue [[Dragon magazine 30|#30]]. It and all other Greenwood articles published in ''Dragon'' are by the original Realms purchase agreement (which applied retroactively to all material published before the summer of 1986) considered canonical.
document_data.Special issues: In the magazine's early years, ''Dragon'' published five "Best of" issues, reprinting highly regarded articles from ''The Strategic Review'' and ''The Dragon''. From 1996 to 2001, ''Dragon Magazine'' published the ''Dragon Annual'', a thirteenth issue of all new content.
